div1.p:
120, 121. (L.)
Maria Braseel
and
Mary Burton
were indicted, for that
they, in a certain open court, near the king's highway, on
Robert Newton
did make an assault, putting him in corporal fear and danger of his life, and stealing from his person one linen stock, one stock-buckle, one hat, and one pair of brass sleeve buttons , February 26 . ++ .

Robert Newton
. I am apprentice to Mr. Asbury behind the Royal Exchange on Friday a st, about eleven at night, I was coming along Fleet-street
,
Mary Braseel
took hold on my hand, and asked me in a loving manner if I had been throwing at cocks, and whether I would give her and the other a glass of wine. I went with them to an house in Wine-Office-Court; the other staid below while I went up stairs with Braseel. She called for a pint of wine, sat down, and pulled me on her lap, and asked me if I would go to bed. I said no. The maid brought the wine up, I paid a shilling for it. Braseel gave me a great many fine words, which I can't express now, and wanted to feel my private parts; she then took out twopence halfpenny (which was all the money I had left after paying for the wine) and kept it; she took the wine and bottle and would not let me drink; we went down stairs, and she let me go out into the court. I stood a little while at the door; because I had spent so much money, and lost the rest, I thought it was not right. The two prisoners came to me there, and fell to hugging me and giving me fine words; then Burton took off my hat and gave it to the other, who put it behind her; then one said to the other, The young man is in liquor, let's loosen his stock; upon which they took it off, and I saw it in Burton's hand afterwards. They then took hold of me, one by one hand and the other by the other, and took out my metal sleeve buttons. I then was afraid they would strip me, and seeing my hat under Braseel's apron took it away by force. They then made the best of their way off, but I went after them for my things, and the prisoners were taken in Fleet-street. I was a little in liquor.

The prisoners said that the prosecutor met them, that he was in Liquor, and pulled them about; they were, they said, afraid of him, that he struck them, and would not let them go one way or other; upon which they charged the watch with him, as he did with them.
